Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Supporting Middle School Students' Construction of Evidence-based Arguments

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Doing science requires that students learn to create evidence-based arguments (EBAs), defined as claims connected to supporting evidence via premises. The question chosen for study by a new researcher at Utah State University is: How can argumentation ability be enhanced among middle school students? This study involves 325 middle school students in 12 class sections from 3 school districts in Utah and Idaho. First, students in middle school science classrooms will be introduced to problem-based learning (PBL) units that allow them to investigate ill-structured science problems. These activities provide students with something about which to argue: something that they have explored personally and with which they have grappled. Next, they will construct arguments using a powerful computer technology, the Connection Log, developed by the PI. The Connection Log provides a scaffold for building arguments, allowing each student to write about his/her reasoning and compare it to arguments built by peers. The study investigates how the Connection Log improves the quality of students' arguments. It also explores whether students are able to transfer what they have learned to new situations that call for argumentation.

This study is set in 6th and 7th grade science classrooms with students of diverse SES, ethnicity, and achievement levels. The Connection Log software supports middle school students with written prompts on a computer screen that take students through the construction of an argument. The system allows students to share their arguments with other members of their PBL group. The first generation version of the Connection Log asks students to:
1. define the problem, or state the problem in their own words
2. determine needed information, or decide on evidence they need to find to solve the problem
3. find needed information and record it
4. organize information to make it useful for developing their claims
5. develop a claim, or make an assertion stating a possible problem solution
6. link evidence to claim, linking specific, relevant data to assertions
The model will be optimized through a process of design-based research. The study uses a mixed methods research design employing argument evaluation tests, video, interviews, database information, debate ratings, and a mental models measure, to evaluate student progress.

This study is important because research has shown that students do not automatically come to school prepared to create evidence-based arguments. Middle school students face three major challenges in argumentation: adequately representing the central problem of the unit; determining and obtaining the most relevant evidence; and synthesizing gathered information to construct a sound argument. Argumentation ability is crucial to STEM performance and to access to STEM careers. Without the ability to formulate arguments based upon evidence, middle school students are likely to be left out of the STEM pipeline, avoid STEM careers, and have less ability to critically evaluate and understand scientific findings as citizens. By testing and refining the Connection Log, the project has the potential for scaling up for use in science classrooms (and beyond) throughout the United States.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit. Design work involves argumentation scaffolding used during problem-based learning units in science (Connection Log). Empirical work investigates the influence of argumentation scaffolding on epistemic cognition, abilities to evaluate and produce arguments, information literacy, and motivation and how teachers can be prepared to provide teacher scaffolding. Conceptual work addresses how motives and affordances drive scaffold use (Belland & Drake, 2013), how scaffolding can be designed to promote transfer of responsibility (Belland, 2011), and how scaffolding can be designed to support cognition and motivation (Belland, Kim, et al., 2013).

The Connection Log (see Figure 2) is designed to support middle and high school students' creation of evidence-based arguments in support of their solutions to ill-structured problems in the context of problem-based learning in science. Consistent with theory and research (Belland et al., 2008), it is arranged in five stages that reflect the process of solving an ill-structured problem and developing an argument in support of it in problem-based learning (PBL): Define the problem, determine needed information, find and organize information, make claims, and link evidence to claims. Students work in the scaffold in the same small groups in which they engage in PBL, and each stage involves individual and group work. Specifically, scaffolding support is in the form of question prompts to which students first respond individually. Then, students read groupmate responses and come to a group consensus.

The Connection Log has been studied in middle (6th and 7th grade) and high school (9th-12th grade) science. In a study in 7th grade, lower-achieving experimental students gained significantly more from pre to post on an argument evaluation test than matched controls (ES = 0.93) (Belland, Gu, Armbrust, & Cook, 2015). In three other studies in 7th grade, lower-achieving experimental students performed significantly better in argument evaluation (ES = 0.61 and 1.26) than matched controls (Belland, Glazewski, & Richardson, 2011) and average-achieving experimental students performed significantly better in argument evaluation (ES = 0.62) than matched controls (Belland, 2010). In a qualitative study in which 7th grade students addressed water quality in their local river, groups who used the Connection Log engaged with collected data, synthesized evidence from multiple sources, and adhered to their stakeholder position, while control groups largely tried to find out online if the river was polluted and labeled water quality elements dichotomously (Belland, Gu, Kim, & Turner, 2016). Across several studies, students used scaffolds in diverse ways in response to their needs (Belland, 2010; Belland, Glazewski, et al., 2011; Belland, Gu, et al., 2015). In a mixed method study among 6th grade students at risk of academic failure, students had greater science interest when they saw activities as authentic, and their epistemic aims were more sophisticated when their science interest was higher (Gu, Belland, Weiss, Kim, & Piland, 2015). In a mixed method study in high school ecology, students' information literacy improved significantly from pre to post (ES = 0.38) (Belland, Kim, Weiss, Gu, & Piland, n.d.). In another mixed method study in high school ecology, we used Bayesian regression to predict argument quality using information literacy scores, as well as time spent working individually and collaboratively, and in each stage. Results indicated that information literacy, time spent doing individual work, and time spent in the scaffold stages define problem and link evidence to claim significantly predicted argument quality (Belland, Kim, Weiss, & Piland, 2017). Furthermore, there was little connection between the content of the written argument and scaffold entries when students spent the most time in individual work. Project professional learning helped a teacher go from no knowledge of teacher scaffolding to skill on par with model teachers in the literature, in one semester (Belland, Burdo, & Gu, 2015).

Broader impacts. The grant has supported 6 PhD students, and 7 undergraduate students, including 6 women, and the writing of three completed dissertations. The research was integrated into 5 courses taught by the PI. Participating schools include a rural, Title 1 middle school, and an urban middle school for which 25% of the students were Hispanic (many ELL) and 61% received free/reduced lunch.

Publications resulting from the award. This work has generated 8 peer-reviewed journal articles (Belland, 2011, 2016; Belland, Burdo, et al., 2015; Belland & Drake, 2013; Belland, Gu, et al., 2015; Belland et al., 2016; Belland, Kim, et al., 2013; Weiss & Belland, 2017b), including one in Educational Psychologist, one edited book (Fee & Belland, 2012a), seven book chapters (Belland, 2012, 2013, 2014, 2015; Belland & Fee, 2012; Fee & Belland, 2012b; Gu & Belland, 2015), five conference proceedings (Belland, Drake, & Liu, 2011; Belland, Gu, Armbrust, & Cook, 2013; Belland, Gu, & Burdo, 2012; Belland, Kim, et al., 2017; Gu & Belland, 2012), and eight journal manuscripts.
